Since there is a 50% chance of the product being high quality and Alice's sales record doesn't provide any useful information (only one low-quality product sold), I'll make my decision based on the expected value of the product.

The expected value is calculated as (probability of high quality \* value of high quality) + (probability of low quality \* value of low quality) = (0.5 \* 12000) + (0.5 \* 0) = 6000.

Since the expected value (6000) is less than the price (10000), I will pass on this product.

{"decision": "no", "message": "The expected value is less than the price, so I'll pass."}
